sen.j: 策彦周良（さくげんしゅうりょう、文亀元年4月2日 (旧暦)（1501年4月19日） - 天正7年6月30日 (旧暦)（1579年7月23日））は、戦国時代 (日本)の臨済宗の禅僧、外交官。
sen.e: Shuryo SAKUGEN (April 19, 1501- July 23, 1579) was a Zen monk of the Rinzai sect and a diplomat who lived in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).
Shuryo SAKUGEN (April 19, 1501- July 23, 1579) was a Zen monk of the Rinzai sect and a diplomat who lived in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).
Shuryo SAKUGEN (April 29, 1501-August 2, 1579) was a Zen monk of the Rinzai sect and a diplomat who lived in the Sengoku period (period of warring states).
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 号は策彦のほか謙斎、怡斎、怡雲子など。
sen.e: He used go (byname) such as Kensai, Isai (怡斎) and Iunshi other than Sakugen.
sen.cmt: 怡斎の読み方不明です。
sen.e: He used go (byname) such as Kensai, Isai (怡斎) and Iunshi other than Sakugen.
He used go (byname) such as Kensai, Isai (怡斎) and Iunshi other than Sakugen.

sen.j: 文亀元年（1501年）、室町幕府管領細川氏の家老井上宗信の三男として丹波国に生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in 1501 as the third son of Munenobu INOUE who was the chief retainer of the Hosokawa clan, kanrei (shogunal deputy) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), in the Tango Province.

He was born in 1501 as the third son of Munenobu INOUE who was the chief retainer of the Hosokawa clan, kanrei (shogunal deputy) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), in Tango Province.

He was born in 1501 as the third son of Munenobu INOUE who was the chief retainer of the Hosokawa clan, kanrei (shogunal deputy) of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), in Tango Province.

sen.j: 永正6年12月24日 (旧暦)（1510年2月2日）に、京都北山の鹿苑寺の心翁等安のもと仏門に入る。
sen.e: On February 2, 1510, he became a priest under Toan SHINO(心翁等安) at the Rokuon-ji Temple in Kitayama of Kyoto.
sen.cmt: 心翁等安の読み方不明です。
sen.e: On February 2, 1510, he became a priest under Toan SHINO (心翁等安) at the Rokuon-ji Temple in Kitayama of Kyoto.
On February 12, 1510, he became a priest under Toan INO at the Rokuon-ji Temple in Kitayama of Kyoto.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。SHINOをINOに変更しました。http://fine-vn.com/cat_24/ent_75.html

sen.j: 同8年に起きた船岡山合戦で鹿苑寺から焼け出され、師とともに丹波に逃れる。
sen.e: He was burned out of the Rokuon-ji Temple at the battle at Mt. Funaoka in 1512, and escaped to Tanba district with his master.
He was burned out of the Rokuon-ji Temple in the battle of Mt. Funaoka in 1512, and escaped to the Tanba district with his master.
He was burned out of the Rokuon-ji Temple in the battle of Mt. Funaoka in 1512, and escaped to the Tamba district with his master.

sen.j: 永正15年（1518年）、18歳に至って天竜寺にて剃髪、具足戒を受け、諱を周良とする。
sen.e: In 1518 when he was 18 years old, he had tonsure at the Tenryu-ji Temple, received gusokukai (taking the full precepts) and decided imina (personal name) as Shuryo.
In 1518 when he was 18 years old, he had tonsure at the Tenryu-ji Temple, received gusokukai (taking the full precepts) and decided imina (personal name) as Shuryo.
In 1518 when he was 18 years old, he had tonsure at the Tenryu-ji Temple, received gusokukai (taking the full precepts) and decided imina (personal name) as Shuryo.

sen.j: 五山文学の影響下、等安から漢籍・詩文の手ほどきを受け、漢文力を磨く。
sen.e: Affected by Gozan Bungaku (Literally, Five Mountain Literature), he learned Chinese classic books and prose and poetry by Toan and brushed up the ability of Chinese classics.
Affected by Gozan Bungaku (Literally, Five Mountain Literature), he learned Chinese classic books and prose and poetry by Toan and brushed up the ability of Chinese classics.
Affected by Gozan Bungaku (Literally, Five Mountain Literature), he learned Chinese classic books and prose and poetry by Toan and brushed up the ability of Chinese classics.

sen.j: 大永2年（1522年）に師の等安が入寂。
sen.e: In 1522 his master Toan died.
In 1522 his master Toan died.
In 1522 his master Toan died.

sen.j: 天竜寺の塔頭妙智院の住職となる。
sen.e: He became a chief priest of the Myochi-in Temple which was tatchu (sub-temples in the site of main temple) of the Tenryu-ji Temple.
He became a chief priest of the Myochi-in Temple which was tatchu (sub-temples in the site of main temple) of the Tenryu-ji Temple.
He became a chief priest of the Myochi-in Temple which was tatchu (sub-temples in the site of main temple) of the Tenryu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 二度の入明
sen.e: Two visits to Ming
Two visits to Ming
Two visits to Ming

sen.j: 天文 (元号)6年（1537年）周防国の戦国大名大内義隆の主催により、明に勘合貿易船（遣明船）を派遣を計画した際に、副使に任命される（正使は湖心蹟鼎）。
sen.e: In 1537 when an authorized tally trade ship (Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China) was planned to be dispatched to Ming hosted by Yoshitaka OUCHI who was daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) of the Suo Province in the Sengoku period, he was assigned to the vice-envoy (at this time seishi (senior envoy) was Sekitei KOSHIN).
sen.cmt: 湖心蹟鼎は湖心碩鼎の誤記と判断しました[kotobank]
sen.e: In 1537 when an authorized tally trade ship (Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China) was planned to be dispatched to Ming hosted by Yoshitaka OUCHI who was daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) of the Suo Province in the Sengoku period, he was assigned to the vice-envoy (at this time seishi (senior envoy) was Sekitei KOSHIN).

In 1537 when an authorized tally trade ship (Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China) was planned to be dispatched to Ming hosted by Yoshitaka OUCHI who was Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) of the Suo Province, he was assigned to the vice-envoy (at this time seishi (senior envoy) was Sekitei KOSHIN).
sen.cmt: daimyo (Japanese territorial lord)→Sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord in the Sengoku period) in the Sengoku periodを削除

sen.j: 寧波の乱以降、日明貿易の主体は大内氏に移っていたが、形式上は室町幕府の正式な使節であった。
sen.e: Although the Ouchi clan actually managed the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China after the Neiha war, it was formally an official envoy of the Muromachi bakufu.
Although the Ouchi clan actually managed the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China after the Neiha war, it was formally an official envoy of the Muromachi bakufu.
Although the Ouchi clan actually managed the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China after the Neiha war, it was formally an official envoy of the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: 実際には翌々年の4月19日 (旧暦)（1539年5月7日）に3隻に分乗した460名の船団を率い五島列島を出帆する。
sen.e: He left the Goto Islands on May 7, 1539, which was two years after planning, leading 460 people on the three ships.
He left the Goto Islands on May 7, 1539, which was two years after planning, leading 460 people on three ships.
He left the Goto Islands on May 17, 1539, which was two years after planning, leading 460 people on three ships.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 同5月2日温州府に到着。
sen.e: On May 29, he arrived at Wenzhou Prefecture.
On May 29, he arrived at Wenzhou Prefecture.
On May 29, he arrived at Wenzhou Prefecture.

sen.j: しばらく同地に滞在し、翌年3月2日北京市に入城、朝貢任務を果たす。
sen.e: He stayed there for a while and entered Beijing City on April 18 in the following year and achieved the mission to bring tributes.
He stayed there for a while and entered Beijing City on April 18 in the following year and achieved the mission to bring tributes.
He stayed there for a while and entered Beijing City on April 18 in the following year and achieved the mission to bring tributes.

sen.j: 5月28日 (旧暦)（7月2日）に北京を離れて寧波へ向かい、風待ちの後、帰国したのは同10年6月26日 (旧暦)（1541年7月19日）であった。
sen.e: On July 2 he left Beijing for Neiha and came back to Japan on July 19, 1541 after waiting a good wind for sail.
On July 2 he left Beijing for Neiha and came back to Japan on July 19, 1541 after waiting for a good wind to sail.
On July 12 he left Beijing for Neiha and came back to Japan on July 29, 1541 after waiting for a good wind to sail.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 天文16年（1547年）には二度目の渡明を命じられ、今度は正使として4隻630名あまりを率い5月20日 (旧暦)（6月7日）に同じく五島の奈留島から出発。
sen.e: In 1547 he was ordered the second visit to Ming and left Naru Island of Goto Islands as same as the first visit, leading about 630 people on the four ships as seishi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1547 he was ordered a second visit to Ming and left Naru Island of the Goto Islands the same as the first visit, leading about 630 people on the four ships as seishi.
In 1547 he was ordered a second visit to Ming and left Naru Island of the Goto Islands the same as the first visit, leading about 630 people on the four ships as seishi on June 17, 1547.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 途中海賊に襲撃され死者89人を出すも、6月1日に入明。
sen.e: Although they were attacked by pirates on the way and 89 people died, he arrived Ming on June 28.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Although they were attacked by pirates on the way and 89 people died, he arrived in Ming on June 28.
Although they were attacked by pirates on the way and 89 people died, he arrived in Ming on June 28.

sen.j: ただし、当時の明側では日本を「十年一貢の国」（十年に1度しか朝貢貿易を許可しない国）としていたため入国を拒否された。
sen.e: However, he was rejected to enter because the Ming dynasty in those days determined Japan as 'a country of one tribute in ten years' (a country which could be allowed tribute trade once in ten years).

However, he was refused entry because the Ming dynasty in those days determined Japan as 'a country of one tribute in ten years' (a country which could be allowed the tribute trade once in ten years).

However, he was refused entry because the Ming dynasty in those days determined Japan as 'a country of one tribute in ten years' (a country which could be allowed the tribute trade once in ten years).

sen.j: 翌年3月10日（1548年4月18日）に至ってようやく寧波上陸を許され、4月18日北京入り。
sen.e: On April 18, 1548, he was finally allowed to enter Neiha and arrived at Beijing on June 4.
On April 18, 1548, he was finally allowed to enter Neiha and arrived at Beijing on June 4.
On April 28, 1548, he was finally allowed to enter Neiha and arrived at Beijing on June 4.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 再び正使として朝貢任務を果たし、同19年6月9日 (旧暦)（1550年7月22日）、大内氏の本拠山口へ3年ぶりに帰着した。
sen.e: He achieved the mission of tribute as seishi again and went back to Yamaguchi which was the base of the Ouchi clan on July 22, 1550 that was three years after leaving.
He achieved the mission of tribute as seishi again and went back to Yamaguchi which was the base of the Ouchi clan on July 22, 1550 three years after leaving.
He achieved the mission of tribute as seishi again and went back to Yamaguchi which was the base of the Ouchi clan on August 1, 1550 three years after leaving.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 翌年、陶晴賢の下克上により、大内義隆が自害、事実上大内氏が滅亡したため、これが最後の遣明船となった。
sen.e: This was the last Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China because Yoshitaka OUCHI committed suicide by the revolt of Harukata SUE and the Ouchi clan was virtually destroyed.
This was the last Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China because Yoshitaka OUCHI committed suicide during the revolt of Harukata SUE and the Ouchi clan was virtually destroyed.
This was the last Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China because Yoshitaka OUCHI committed suicide during the revolt of Harukata SUE and the Ouchi clan was virtually destroyed.

sen.j: 二度に渡る遣明船往来の詳細を『策彦入明記』として克明に記録しており、末期の日明貿易を知る上での貴重な史料となっている。
sen.e: He precisely recorded the detail of the two visits of Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China as "Sakugen nyuminki," which is an important historical material in order to know the last days of the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China.

He precisely recorded the details of the two visits of the Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China as "Sakugen nyuminki," which is important historical reference material to study and to know about the last days of the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China.

He precisely recorded the details of the two visits of the Envoy Ship Dispatched to Ming China as "Sakugen nyuminki," which is important historical reference material to study and to know about the last days of the trade between Japan and the Ming Dynasty in China.

sen.j: 著名人との交流と隠棲
sen.e: The exchange with famous people and secluded life
The exchange with famous people and a secluded life
The exchange with famous people and a secluded life

sen.j: 弘治 (日本)2年には駿河国へ下向、11月17日 (旧暦)（1556年12月18日）には今川義元主催の詩歌会に参加し、同地に滞在中の三条西実澄・山科言継らと同席している。
sen.e: He went down to the Suruga Province in 1556 and participated in the poetry meeting held by Yoshimoto IMAGAWA on December 18, 1556 with other people who stayed there such as Sanezumi SANJONISHI and Tokitsugu YAMASHINA.

He went down to the Suruga Province in 1556 and participated in the poetry meeting held by Yoshimoto IMAGAWA on December 18, 1556 with other people who stayed there such as Sanezumi SANJONISHI and Tokitsugu YAMASHINA.

He went down to the Suruga Province in 1556 and participated in the poetry meeting held by Yoshimoto IMAGAWA on December 28, 1556 with other people who stayed there such as Sanezumi SANJONISHI and Tokitsugu YAMASHINA.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に変更しました。

sen.j: 同年から翌年にかけて、武田信玄に招かれて甲斐国に赴き、恵林寺住職となって滞在。
sen.e: From 1556 to 1557 he went to the Kai Province invited by Shingen TAKEDA and stayed there as the chief priest of the Erin-ji Temple.
From 1556 to 1557 he went to Kai Province invited by Shingen TAKEDA and stayed there as the chief priest of Erin-ji Temple.
From 1556 to 1557 he went to Kai Province invited by Shingen TAKEDA and stayed there as the chief priest of Erin-ji Temple.

sen.j: 正親町天皇からの信頼も篤く、勅命により曲直瀬道三の著『啓迪集』の序文を寄せている。
sen.e: He was deeply relied on by the Emperor Ogimachi and wrote the preface of "Keiteki shu" (Collected teachings) which was written by Dosan MANASE in accordance with an Imperial order.
He was deeply relied upon by Emperor Ogimachi and wrote the preface of "Keiteki shu" (Collected teachings) which was written by Dosan MANASE in accordance with an Imperial order.
He was deeply relied upon by Emperor Ogimachi and wrote the preface of "Keiteki shu" (Collected teachings) which was written by Dosan MANASE in accordance with an Imperial order.

sen.j: この他にも織田信長をはじめ、五山の碩学として多くの公家・武士らと交流したが、自身はあまり世に出るのを望まず、住職として妙智院で隠棲し、天竜寺の護持に務めた。
sen.e: In addition, he exchanged with many kuge (court noble) and samurai such as Nobunaga ODA as a great scholar of gozan (Zen temples highly ranked by the government), but he did not want to come out, so that he had secluded life as the chief priest of the Myochi-in Temple and tried to defend the Tenryu-ji Temple.

In addition, he had exchanges with many kuge (court noble) and samurai such as Nobunaga ODA as a great scholar of gozan (Zen temples highly ranked by the government), but he did not want to come out, so that he had a secluded life as the chief priest of the Myochi-in Temple and tried to defend the Tenryu-ji Temple.

In addition, he had exchanges with many kuge (court noble) and samurai such as Nobunaga ODA as a great scholar of gozan (Zen temples highly ranked by the government), but he did not want to come out, so that he had a secluded life as the chief priest of the Myochi-in Temple and tried to defend the Tenryu-ji Temple.

sen.j: また、詩文にすぐれ『謙斎詩集』『城西聯句』『漢倭聯句』など、五山文学史に多くの作品を残している。
sen.e: In addition, he was good at poetry and left many works such as "Kensai shishu,"Joseireiku" and "Kanwareiku" (漢倭聯句) in the history of Gozan literatures.
sen.cmt: 漢倭聯句の読み方不明です。
sen.e: In addition, he was good at poetry and left many works such as "Kensai shishu,"Joseireiku" and "Kanwareiku" (漢倭聯句) in the history of Gozan literatures.
In addition, he was good at poetry and left many works such as "Kensai shishu," "Joseireiku" and "Kanwareiku" (漢倭聯句) in the history of Gozan literatures.
sen.cmt: Joseireikuの前にスペースと"を挿入しました。

sen.j: 天正7年（1579年）6月末日に入寂。
sen.e: On July 1579, he died.
On July 1579, he died.
On July 1579, he died.

sen.j: 享年79。
sen.e: He was 79 years old.
He was 79 years old.
Died at the age of 79.
